H0.text: The summer solstice occurs when the North Pole is tilted toward the Sun and the United States has its most daylight hours of the year.

H1.text: Winter solstice occurs when the North Pole is tilted toward the Sun and the United States has the most daylight hours of the year.

H2.text: Spring equinox occurs when the North Pole is tilted toward the Sun and the United States has the most daylight hours of the year.

H3.text: The fall equinox occurs when the North Pole is tilted toward the Sun and the United States has the most daylight hours of the year.

A4.text: The summer solstice or estival solstice occurs when one of Earth's poles has its maximum tilt toward the Sun.

A5.text: The opposite event is the winter solstice.
